Walking through its corridors, I felt a sense of deep peace and tranquility, as if the weight of everyday life was lifted. The gentle sea breeze from the Arabian Sea, just steps away from the temple, added to the calming ambiance, making it a perfect place for reflection and spiritual connection. The energy of Somnath is palpable, and the spiritual solace it provides is indescribable. Whether youre a pilgrim or simply someone seeking peace, this temple is truly a divine sanctuary.

name: Amit J
review_text:
The Somnath temple, located in Prabhas Patan, Veraval, Gujarat, is a prominent Hindu temple and the first among the twelve jyotirlinga shrines of Shiva. Its origins are uncertain, but it is believed to date back to the 1st millennium CE. The temple has been destroyed and rebuilt several times due to invasions by various Muslim rulers, starting with Mahmud Ghazni in the 11th century. After India's independence, it was rebuilt in the Maru-Gurjara style under Vallabhbhai Patel's directive, with support from Mahatma Gandhi, and completed in 1951.

Strategically positioned along Gujarat's coastline, the temple is about 400 kilometers southwest of Ahmedabad. Historically, it was a significant trading port and a revered jyotirlinga site, known as Somnath, or "Lord of the Soma." Despite repeated destruction, the temple has been a symbol of resilience and Hindu heritage. The current structure showcases intricate carvings and remains a major pilgrimage site, symbolizing the enduring spirit of Hinduism.

name: R Ramesh
review_text:
The Somnath Temple, nestled in Prabhas Patan near Veraval in Gujarat, is an awe-inspiring marvel of ancient architecture and spiritual significance. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, this revered Jyotirlinga shrine has a storied past marked by numerous reconstructions due to invasions and natural disasters. The current temple, reconstructed under the leadership of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel in the 1950s, blends traditional design with modern resilience.

Architecturally, the temples grandeur is undeniable. Its intricately carved spires and expansive courtyards are adorned with exquisite stonework that exemplifies the artistry of ancient Indian craftsmen. The temples primary sanctum, with its golden shikhara (spire), is an imposing and beautiful sight, enhanced by its coastal location overlooking the Arabian Sea.

A unique feature of the Somnath Temple is its alignment with the South Pole. This alignment was discovered during the recent reconstruction, showcasing the advanced astronomical understanding of its creators. The precision of this alignment adds a profound dimension to the temple's already deep spiritual significance.

The temple complex also offers an engaging evening experience with its spectacular laser show. Held against the backdrop of the majestic temple, the show vividly recounts the temple's rich history and mythology through a blend of light, sound, and narration. This visual spectacle not only enhances the visitors understanding of the temple's historical journey but also provides a breathtaking conclusion to a day of spiritual reflection.

Overall, the Somnath Temple is a confluence of historical grandeur, architectural beauty, and spiritual resonance. Its unique celestial alignment and captivating evening laser show make it a profound destination for visitors seeking both cultural enrichment and spiritual solace.

name: Anuj Tripathi
review_text:
Many Hindu texts provide a list of the most sacred Shiva pilgrimage sites, along with a guide for visiting the site. The best known were the Mahatmya genre of texts. Of these, Somnatha temple tops the list of jyotirlingas in the Jnanasamhita - chapter 13 of the Shiva Purana, and the oldest known text with a list of jyotirlingas. Other texts include the Varanasi Mahatmya (found in Skanda Purana), the Shatarudra Samhita and the Kothirudra Samhita . All either directly mention the Somnath temple as the number one of twelve sites, or call the top temple as Somesvara in Saurashtra - a synonymous term for this site in these texts. The exact date of these texts is unknown, but based on references they make to other texts and ancient poets or scholars, these have been generally dated between the 10th and 12th century, with some dating it much earlier and others a bit later.

The Somnath temple is not mentioned in ancient Sanskrit texts of Hinduism, but the Prabhasa-Pattana is mentioned as a tirtha (pilgrimage site). For example, the Mahabharata (c. 400 CE in its mature form)[citation needed] in Chapters 109, 118 and 119 of the Book Three (Vana Parva), and Sections 10.45 and 10.78 of the Bhagavata Purana state Prabhasa to be a tirtha on the coastline of Saurashtra

Mughal invaders destroyed the temple numerous times, looted the valuables and broke the Shiv Ling.

About Place: The intricately carved honey-colored Somnath temple on the western edge of the state is believed to be the place where the first of the twelve holy jyotirlingas emerged in India - a spot where Shiva appeared as a fiery column of light.

Location-
The Somnath temple is located along the coastline in Prabhas Patan, Veraval, Saurashtra region of Gujarat. It is about 400 kilometres (249 mi) southwest of Ahmedabad, 82 kilometres (51 mi) south of Junagadh - another major archaeological and pilgrimage site in Gujarat.

Mahmud Ghazni has plundered and destroyed Somnath Temple 17 times along with other temples in his attacks. Mahmud Ghazni was the King of Ghazni (Afghanistan) who ruled there from 999-1030 AD. He plundered a lot many kingdoms and temples of India.

If you are short on time, you can cover both Dwarka Somnath tour in 3-4 days. However, if you want to explore the surrounding areas and nearby attractions, you may need to spend more time.

The first of Indias twelve sacred jyotirlingas is said to have arisen at the elaborately carved honey-colored Somnath temple on the states western border. It is said that Shiva manifested there as a blazing column of light.

The temples are situated where the Sarasvati, Hiran, and Kapila rivers converge, and the shoreline where they are built is touched by the ebb and flow of the Arabian Sea.

Although the history of the ancient temple starts in 649 BC, it is thought to be earlier. In 1951, the current shape was rebuilt. Though its difficult to see them through the foggy glass, vibrant dioramas depicting the Shiva narrative border the north side of the temple grounds.

There are legends that the moon deity Somraj initially constructed a gold temple at Somnath, which was then rebuilt in stone by Bhimdev, in wood by Krishna, and in silver by Ravana. On the original beachfront location, the calm, symmetrical edifice that stands today was constructed in accordance with traditional ideas. It has a creamy hue and some exquisite sculpture. One of the 12 most revered Shiva temples, or jyotirlinga, is the enormous, black Shiva lingam in its centre.

name: vasu deva reddy Nagari
review_text:
The Somnath temple is located in Prabhas Patan in Saurashtra, West Gujarat in India.

It is considered to be the first of the jyotirlingas

It is believed that the original temple was built by the Moon God with gold in the Satya Yuga; by Ravana in Treta Yuga in silver; and by Lord Krishna in Dwapara Yuga in sandalwood.

This temple has been looted and demolished many times by various invaders - by Mahmud of Ghazni (1024), Afzal Khan, Ala-ud-din Khilji's commander (1296), Muzaffar Shah (1375), Mahmud Begada (1451), and later Aurangzeb (1665).

Many rulers reconstructed the temple: Shri Vikramaditya of Ujjaini (about 2500 years ago), the Vallabhi kings (in the period 480-767 CE), Bhimadeva of Anhilawada (in 11th century AD), and Khangara, the king of Junagadh (in 1351 AD) among many others.

It has been reconstructed about 17 times! The modern structure has been constructed by India's former deputy Prime Minister Sardar Vallabhai Patel between 1947 and 1951 in sandstone.

After visiting Somnath Temple, Im eager to explore more, particularly the Balka Teerth, where other shivlingas are located within the sea, accessible only during low tide. Shri Somnath Temple, also known as Somnath Temple or Dev Patan, is a Hindu temple located in Prabhas Patan, Veraval, Gujarat, India. This temple is situated at the western end of Gujarat at the confluence of Kapila, Hiran and Saraswati rivers. It is painted creamy and has a large, black Shiva Linga.

First construction: It is said that Chandradev Somraj built a temple of gold.
Reconstruction: This temple was rebuilt by Ravana with silver, Krishna with wood and Bhimdev with stone.
Consecration: The existing temple was inaugurated on 11 May 1951 by the then President of India, Dr. Rajendra Prasad.
The temple is open every day from 6 am to 10 pm. The nearest railway station is Veraval, and the nearest airports are Diu, Rajkot, Ahmedabad and Vadodara.

The history of Somnath temple is as follows:

The Somnath Temple is built on the seashore at Veraval port in the Saurashtra region of Gujarat.

This is the first Jyotirlinga among the 12 Jyotirlingas of Lord Shiva.

The glory of Somnath temple is described in Mahabharata, Shrimad Bhagwat, Skanda Purana, and Rigveda.

Mythological belief is that this temple was built by Chandradev.

According to legends, Chandradev had performed penance considering Lord Shiva as his Nath.

This temple has been looted many times and has also been rebuilt.

Some major attacks on Somnath Temple:

Mahmud Ghaznavi attacked this temple in 1024 AD.

Alauddin Khilji attacked this temple in 1296.

Mughal emperor Aurangzeb tried to attack this temple in 1701.

Somnath temple is considered one of the most prominent temples of India.

review_text:
The name Somnath alone is enough to make the body tingle. The first Jyotirlinga and the oldest temple in the country is the Somnath temple in Gujarat. According to Purana, Chandradeva Prajapati married 27 daughters of Daksha Raja, but he was more attracted to one wife/ the remaining 26 wives felt humiliated and the father complained to Daksha Raja. Hearing this, the king got angry and cursed Chandradev that his form and size would diminish day by day. Chandradeva then started worshiping Lord Shiva on the shores of the Arabian Sea, Mahadeva was pleased with his worship and reduced his curse by half at the sight. That is, until the full moon, Chandradev will regain his full form and size, and after the full moon, he will gradually lose weight. Chandradev built a golden Shiva temple at this place. This temple was destroyed 17 times by enemies and then rebuilt by devotees. The temple we see now was renovated by Vallabh Bhai Patel, the Iron Man Sardar of Gujarat. A statue of him is erected in front of the temple. The temple is open from 6 am to 10 pm. The light and sound show starts from 8 pm in the temple premises, except during the rainy season. The history of Somnath is highlighted through the Bhasyapath of Gujarat tourism brand ambasadar Shri Abhithav Bachchan. Details video is given on U Tube.

name: KABIR RAJPUT
review_text:
Somnath Temple or Dev Patan is a Hindu temple located in Veraval, Prabhas Patan, Gujarat, India. It is one of the holiest pilgrimage sites for Hindus and the first of the twelve jyotirlingas of Shiva. It is not clear when the first version of the Somnath temple was built, with estimates varying between the early centuries of the 1st millennium CE and around the 9th century CE. Ancient Sanskrit texts of Hinduism do not mention the temple as Somnatha Namkarana, but Prabhas-pattan (Prabhas Patan) as the tirtha (place of pilgrimage), where this temple exists. For example, chapters 109, 118, and 119 of Book 3 (Vana Parva) of the Mahabharata and sections 10.45 and 10.78 of the Bhagavata Purana Rajya Prabhas are shrines on the coast of Saurashtra. The present Somnath temple was rebuilt in the Maru-Gurjara style of Hindu temple architecture. The reconstruction of the contemporary Somnath temple was started under the orders of Vallabhbhai Patel, the first Deputy Prime Minister of India, after getting approval for the reconstruction from Mahatma Gandhi. Reconstruction was completed in May 1951 after Gandhis death.

The holy place Somnath Temple is considered to be the first of the 12 Jyotirlingas of Lord Shiva. It is said that it was built by Chandradev Somraj himself, whose mention is found in Rigveda.

It is said that the Arab traveler Al Beruni had written its description in his travelogue, which was influenced by the invader Mahmud Ghaznavi who attacked the temple in 1025. Ghaznavi looted the property of the temple and almost destroyed it. Regarding the horror of that attack, it is said that Ghaznavi had attacked the Somnath temple with about 5,000 people. Thousands of unarmed people were killed while protecting the temple. Among them were those people who were either worshiping here or taking advantage of darshan inside the temple. There were also people who lived in the surrounding villages and ran to protect the temple.

The temple was destroyed several times by Mughal rulers and rebuilt by Hindu kings.
The last reconstruction was done by Queen Ahilya Bai Holkar in the 17th century, which is known as the Old Somnath Temple.

The temple that is standing today was rebuilt by Indias Home Minister Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel in 1950. It was dedicated to the nation by the President of India Shankar Dayal Sharma on 1st December 1995. This temple is known as the new Somnath Temple which is very grand.

name: Arun Kumar
review_text:
The Somnath Temple stands on the shores of the Arabian Sea in the western corner of the Indian subcontinent in the state of Gujarat. This Yatra is an ancient one and its reference can be found in ancient texts like Skandpuran, Srimad Bhagavad, Shivapuran. The hymn of the Rig-Veda quoted below mentions the great pilgrimage of Lord Someshwar and Gangaji, Yamunaji and Sarasvati towards the east. This indicates the ancient value of this tirtha.

Prabhas is in Patan which is very close to Somnath Veraval.

It is said that the moon god was freed from the curse of his father-in-law Daksha Prajapati by the blessings of Lord Somnath. In Shiva Purana and Nandi Upapurana, Shiva says, ``I am always everywhere, but especially in 12 forms and places as Jyotirlingas. Somnath is one of these 12 holy places. This is the first of the twelve holy Shiva Jyotirlinga.

The shore temple of Somnath is believed to have been built in 4 phases by Lord Soma, Ravi in   silver, Krishna under the tree in wood and King Bhimadeva in stone.

It has endured six desecrations by Muslim invaders. The presence of this temple is a symbol of the restorative spirit and cultural unity of our society.

The present seventh temple is built in Kailash Mahameru Prasad style. Indias iron man Sardar Sri Vallabhbhai Patel was the pioneer of the present temple.

The temple consists of Garbru, Saphamandap and Nridhyamandap with 150 feet high shikar. The Kalash on top of the Shikhar weighs 10 tons and the Dhwajdand is 27 feet tall and 1 foot in circumference.

1/1612 First among Jyotirlingas



According to the belief of Hinduism, the twelve places where Lord Shiva manifested Himself are worshiped in the form of Jyotirlinga. Shri Somnath in Gujarats Saurashtra ranks first among them. Shiva devotees from all over the world come here to see the magnificent Shivalinga. But there are lesser known things about Somnath temple in Gujarat which very few devotees know about.

2/16 Last renovated in 1951:



Somnath Temple has been a symbol of the rise and fall of Hinduism in India. The Muslim rulers tried to demolish this temple several times but the Somnath temple is standing again. The temple you see now was renovated between 1947 and 1951 after independence. President of India Dr. It was inaugurated by Rajendra Prasad.

3/16Syamantaka Mani:



It is believed that the Syamantaka Mani is hidden in the cavity of the Shivlinga of Somnath. This gem is associated with Lord Shri Krishna. It is believed that whoever it touches becomes gold. This gem is believed to have radioactive properties. According to the belief, it is because of the magnetic field of this gem that the Shivlinga is standing so high above the ground.

4/16 Fifty thousand people died in the temple:



When Sultan Mahmud came to India, he ended the religious war. He made several attempts to demolish the Somnath temple with the intention of converting the Hindus into Mohammedans. He reached Somnath in December 1025 and the Indians made several attempts to stop him there. Thousands of people rushed to the temple crying for help. He continued to fight the Sultan from the temple till his last breath. According to an estimate, 50 thousand people lost their lives in this war.

5/16 Treasure looted:



After the victory, the Sultan was amazed to see the statues in this temple. He ordered to loot the treasure of this temple. Many of these idols were made of gold and silver. Along with this, countless valuable utensils, ornaments etc. were also looted.

6/16 Idol hanging in the air:



The Sultan was stunned to see the idol hanging in the air in the Somnath temple. The idol was seen floating in the air without any visible support. On investigation, the Sultan found that the idol was made of iron. The craftsman who made it arranged magnets around it in such a way that the idol could be suspended in mid-air. When two stones were removed from the top of the temple, the idol leaned to one side. As more stones were removed, the idol fell on the ground.

7/16 Mention in Veda Purana:



Somnath Temple is mentioned in Veda Purana. This temple located on the western coast of Gujarat is also mentioned in Srimad Bhagavata, Skanda Purana, Shiva Purana, Rig Veda. Somnath is a very big pilgrimage for Hindus.

8/16 Vallabhbhai Patel renovated:



Over the years, many Muslim kings have tried to demolish this temple, but each time Hindu kings have rebuilt it and set the precedent. Finally in November 1947, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel visited the area and decided to renovate the temple. Kanaiyalal Maneklal Munshi took responsibility for its restoration after Patels death.

9/16Triveni Sangam:



According to historians, there was a confluence of three rivers namely Kapila, Heeran and Saraswati near Somnath in ancient times. It is believed that the moon deity, who had lost his luster due to a curse, regained his form by taking a bath in the river Saraswati here.

10/16 Sometimes the temple was made of gold-silver and sandalwood:



According to the belief, Chandra Dev was happy to get rid of his curse and built a golden temple in Somnath. After that Shiva devotee Ravana built a silver temple in Somnath. It is also mentioned that Dwarkadhish Krishna Bhagwan built this temple with sandal wood during his reign.

A study of the ancient scriptures of India reveals that the Somnath Jyotirlinga was established and the Prana pratishtha was established on the third day of the Shukla Paksha of the month of Shravan in the Treta Yuga.
